column1: Manx
column2: English

column1: Cha vel caslys jeh. - Ta mee er reayll arrey
column2: There is no sign of him – I have kept watch

column1: Derrey tan eayst ny lie - cha vel eh cheet.
column2: Until the moon has set – he does not come.

column1: Van tra ayn keayrt nagh row eh ve myr shen.
column2: Once there was a time when he wasn’t like that.

column1: Sbeg smooinaght teh kys ta ny jeir shoh shilley,
column2: How little he thinks how these tears fall,

column1: Chouds teh freayll seose e oayllyn feaie sy valley.
column2: Whilst he upholds his wild habits in the town.

column1: Tra hig eh, bee eh trodjey - as neems keayney -
column2: When he comes he will cause trouble – and I’ll cry

column1: As dooishtee eh my oikans meen ass cadley.
column2: And he’ll wake my dear baby out of sleep.

column1: O shinney lhiam ve jeeaghyn er my lhiannoo -
column2: O I love to watch my little child –

column1: E hooillyn dooint saveenys - e ghruaie mei[1] oney -
column2: His eyes closed in slumber – his chubby innocent face -
column3: [1] mei—this word is not attested elsewhere. Likely to be a misspelling of mea—‘plump’ (Fockleyr B-G, Kelly. J.). MEA— a. fat, luscious, rich. Mwannal mea, a thick neck. (Fockleyr B-G, Kelly J.)

column1: E veill veg villish - geddrymagh my chree,
column2: His sweet little lips – lightening my heart,

column1: Ga laadit trome lesh seaghyn as souaigney.
column2: Though heavyladen with sorrows and anguish.

column1: Keayrt dy row va sheshey aym hug graih dou;
column2: Once upon a time I had a partner who loved me;

column1: Agh nish, cre cha caghlaait! - e hilley deuil -
column2: But now, how changed! His cruel sight –

column1: Lesh gruig[2] y chonnysan[3], Cha vel e chree
column2: With the frown of his taunts, His heart is
column3: [2] gruig—grouig, s. f. a frown; pl. —yn. (Cregeen).
column4: [3] y chonnysan—e chonnysyn—'his taunts’. Connyss, Connyssid,— s. a teasing, derision, taunt.

column1: Ny sodjey liams, agh dan venoanjer currit.
column2: No longer mine, but given to the harlot.

column1: Myr shellan, cleaynit liorish losser aalin,
column2: Like a bee, attracted by a beautiful flame,

column1: Teh jiole soo niunagh veih yn vlaa vaasoil.
column2: He sucks poisonous sap from the deadly blossom.

column1: Ny yei cha voddym dwoaie da. O yn tra,
column2: Nevertheless, I cannot hate him. O the time!

column1: Cuin dod me sniemmey liantagh er e oie[4]!
column2: When I could join, united with him in the night!

column1: Ayns fea eisht heel y tra dy meeley shiaghey-
column2: In peace then, the time sneaked past gently,

column1: Blaaghyn dy vaanrys skeaylley er e chassan.
column2: Blossoms of happiness spreading on his path.

column1: Eisht hug me graih da - as ve graiagh orrym
column2: Then I loved him – and he loved me

column1: As ta my chree eer nish chow huggey, tra
column2: And even now my heart is warm towards him, when

column1: Teh gennal as gerjoil myr dooinney cooie :-
column2: He’s cheerful and comforting like a proper man:-

column1: Nyn mreearey bra cha voddym y yarood.
column2: I can never forget our vow.

column1: As ga teh mennic gah mee lesh e hengey -
column2: And though he often stings me with his tongue –

column1: Yn tide ta lottey geyre - chouds teh barrail
column2: The arrow that sharply wounds – whilst he wastes

column1: Yn dooie erreeish ta car dan sluight ain hene,
column2: The kindness of feeling righfully our own offspring’s

column1: Er sheshaght whaagh, kione chiollagh failt y joaree,
column2: On strange company, in front of the strangers
welcoming hearth.

column1: As ga dy yioole eh rhym - ny yei neem surral.
column2: And though he rejects me – nevertheless, I’ll suffer.

column1: Eeer nish dy daragh da ve lie lag ching,
column2: Even now, if he were to become weak and sick,

column1: As guint lesh doghan accanagh as treih -
column2: And hurt by a sick and miserable and illness,

column1: Er shen, ayns chymmey soaillyn yn aggair,
column2: Then in a testament of the wrappings of injustice,

column1: As eh, fierrey[5] dobberan, goghe rish
column2: And him, finally mourning, would admit
column3: [5] fierrey—usual spellings; fy-yerrey, fey-yerrey, also fayeiy.

column1: Yn assee duill[6] mee - as cre wheesh my ghraih.
column2: The hurt I suffered, and how much is my love.
column3: [6] duill—past tense of; fuillagh or fuillaghtyn, v. allowing, permitting, suffering to be done,
